rdf:Description.ns1:label: Pinus nigra
rdf:Description.ns1:abstract: Pinus nigra, the Austrian pine or black pine, is a moderately variable species of pine, occurring across Southern Europe from the Iberian Peninsula to the eastern Mediterranean, on the Anatolian peninsula of Turkey, Corsica and Cyprus, as well as Crimea and in the high mountains of Northwest Africa.
rdf:Description.ns1:habitat:
Pinus nigra is a tree of the Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub biome . The majority of the range is in Turkey. It is found in the higher elevations of the South Apennine mixed montane forests ecoregion in southern Italy and the Tyrrhenian-Adriatic sclerophyllous and mixed forests ecoregion in Sicily. There are remnant populations in the Mediterranean conifer and mixed forests ecoregion, and in the higher Atlas Mountains in Morocco and Algeria.
Pinus nigra Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub biome South Apennine mixed montane forests ecoregion Tyrrhenian-Adriatic sclerophyllous and mixed forests Mediterranean conifer and mixed forests Atlas Mountains
citation needed citation needed citation needed It is found at elevations ranging from sea level to 2,000 m (6,600 ft), most commonly from 250–1,600 m (820–5,250 ft). Several of the varieties have distinct English names.
It needs full sun to grow well, is intolerant of shade , and is resistant to snow and ice damage.
intolerant of shade
citation needed citation needed citation needed It has naturalized in parts of the midwestern states of the United States, normally south of the normal native ranges of native pines.
normally south of the normal native ranges of native pines.
clarification needed clarification needed clarification needed
citation needed citation needed citation needed
rdf:Description.ns1:ecology:
Bonsai Pinus nigra Bonsai Pinus nigra Pinus nigra In Mediterranean Europe and the Anatolian Peninsula ( Asia Minor ), trees usually associated with this species include Scots pine ( Pinus sylvestris ), Serbian spruce ( Picea omorika ), Bosnian pine ( Pinus heldreichii ), Norway spruce ( Picea abies ), Taurus cedar ( Cedrus libani ), European silver fir ( Abies alba ) and related firs . Several species of juniper ( Juniperus spp.), and various broadleaf trees are associates.
Anatolian Peninsula Asia Minor Scots pine Pinus sylvestris Serbian spruce Picea omorika Bosnian pine Pinus heldreichii Norway spruce Picea abies Cedrus libani Cedrus libani European silver fir Abies alba firs juniper Juniperus broadleaf trees
citation needed citation needed citation needed
rdf:Description.ns1:taxonomy:
The species is divided into two subspecies, each further subdivided into three varieties.
Some authorities (e.g. Flora Europaea ) treat several of the varieties at subspecific rank, but this reflects tradition rather than sound taxonomy, as the distinctions between the taxa are small.
Flora Europaea Flora Europaea
Subspecies Subspecies P. nigra subsp. nigra in the east of the range, from Austria, northeast and central Italy, east to the Crimea and Turkey. Needles stout, rigid, 1.5–2 mm diameter, with 3–6 layers of thick-walled hypodermal cells. P. nigra subsp. nigra var. nigra (syn. Pinus nigra var. austriaca , Pinus nigra subsp. dalmatica ) (Austrian pine): Austria, Balkans (except southern Greece). P. nigra subsp. nigra var. caramanica (Turkish black pine): Turkey, Cyprus, southern Greece. P. nigra subsp. nigra var. italica (Italian black pine): central Italy (Villetta Barrea, in Abruzzo National Park) P. nigra subsp. nigra var. pallasiana (syn. Pinus nigra subsp. pallasiana ) (Crimean pine): Crimea, Cyprus. P. nigra subsp. salzmannii in the west of the range, from southern Italy to southern France, Spain and North Africa. Needles slender, more flexible, 0.8–1.5 mm diameter, with 1–2 layers of thin-walled hypodermal cells. P. nigra subsp. salzmannii var. salzmannii (Pyrenean pine): Pyrenees, Southern France, Northern Spain. P. nigra subsp. salzmannii var. corsicana (syn. Pinus nigra subsp. laricio , Pinus nigra var. maritima ) (Corsican pine): Corsica, Sicily, Southern Italy. P. nigra subsp. laricio Koekelare
P. nigra subsp. salzmannii var. mauretanica (Atlas Mountains black pine): Morocco, Algeria.
